In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

Sure! Here's a sample function `add_yearmonth` that achieves this in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame, col::Symbol)
    df.ym = map(row -> Dates.yearmonth(row), df[!, col])
    df.ym = map(ym -> parse(Int, Dates.format(ym, "yyyymm")), df.ym)
    return df
end

# Example usage
df = DataFrame(dt = [DateTime("2022-01-15"), DateTime("2022-02-20"), DateTime("2022-03-25")])
df = add_yearmonth(df, :dt)
```

This function will add a new column `ym` to the DataFrame `df` containing the concatenated year and month values in the format you specified.
